title: 103_hr912
content: SEC. 2. REPEAL OF LIMITATION ON PASSIVE ACTIVITY LOSSES AND CREDITS. This section repeals Section 469 regarding passive activity losses and credits. The effective date for this repeal is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1993. The amendments in this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 1993. It also includes the restoration of a 10-percent investment tax credit. The amendments in this section introduce a general investment credit equal to 10 percent of qualified investment for any taxable year. Qualified investment includes the basis of new section 38 property placed in service by the taxpayer. The general investment credit is 10 percent of qualified investment for a taxable year, which includes the cost of used section 38 property placed in service. The applicable percentage for each property is determined under specific rules, and the term 'section 38 property' refers to tangible personal property. The general investment credit is 10 percent of qualified investment for a taxable year, including the cost of tangible personal property defined as 'section 38 property'. This property must be used in manufacturing, production, transportation, or research facilities for bulk storage of commodities. The term 'section 38 property' includes property used for bulk storage of fungible commodities, elevators, escalators, single purpose agricultural structures, and storage facilities for petroleum distribution. It encompasses property eligible for depreciation or amortization without regard to useful life. The subsection outlines rules for property eligible for depreciation or amortization with a useful life of 3 years or more. It does not apply if other credits like the energy credit or rehabilitation credit would apply unless waived by the taxpayer. Technical amendments include changes to section 49(a)(1) regarding the basis of new section 38 property. The amendment adds new rules for section 38 property with a 3-year useful life, adjusting percentages and excluding certain clauses. Additionally, technical changes are made to section 48 heading. SEC. 48. OTHER CREDITS amended by striking item related to section 48 and inserting "Sec. 48. Other credits." Effective date applies to periods after enactment. SEC. 5. 50 PERCENT DEDUCTION FOR CERTAIN CAPITAL GAINS added to tax laws for non-corporate taxpayers. For non-corporate taxpayers, a 50 percent deduction is allowed for qualified net capital gains. Qualified net capital gain is determined by considering gain or loss from qualified assets with a holding period of at least 1 year. Qualified assets exclude stock or securities traded on an established market. For estates and trusts, the deduction for gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets is computed by excluding the portion includible by income beneficiaries. Corporations can deduct 50 percent of qualified net capital gains under section 1201. The term "qualified net capital gain" is defined in section 1202(b). Amendments are made to sections 1, 1201, and 62 to include references to qualified net capital gain. Section 1201 heading is also amended. SEC. 1201 and 1202 are amended to include alternative tax for corporations and deduction for certain capital gains. The amendments apply to sales and exchanges after the enactment date. SEC. 6 increases deductible health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. SEC. 6 increases deductible health insurance costs for self-employed individuals, making the deduction permanent and increasing it to 100 percent starting in taxable years after December 31, 1992. SEC. 7 repeals Section 141 of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, restoring income averaging. The repeal applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993. SEC. 8 introduces modifications in Social Security taxes. The text chunk discusses the removal of the ceiling on wages subject to tax for FICA and SECA taxes, as well as a reduction in Social Security taxes for employees. The text chunk discusses amendments to FICA and SECA taxes, including a tax rate of 4.55% on wages for employees and employers, and a 6.82% tax on self-employment income. Amendments are made to various sections related to FICA and SECA taxes, including changes in computation of wages, concurrent employment, federal service, and returns for governmental employees. Amendments are made to sections 3201(b), 3211(a)(2), and 3221(b) regarding taxes, with changes in the definition of applicable base for railroad retirement tax purposes. Amendments to various sections of the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are made, including changes to compensation definitions, tax bases, special refunds for employees, and the effective date of the amendments. Amendments to the Social Security Act and Internal Revenue Code include changes to compensation definitions, tax bases, special refunds for employees, and effective date of amendments.
